userreviews.userReview: I thought Fiona McIntosh's first foray into historical fiction was a great read; two strong, male protagonists, exotic locations, secrets, deception, love triangle. She really covered all bases. And then the icing on the cake was in the author's note at the end, where she reveals that she borrowed liberally from her own family history for the major characters and some of the key plot points. Wow! My only criticism is that it all got a bit too melodramatic towards the end, but it wasn't enough to spoil my enjoyment.
Beautiful and evocative, an epic, sprawling tale. Loved it.

In Fields of Gold Fiona McIntosh branches out from her usual genre of fantasy into sagas/historical fiction. As such, the book is very different from what I've otherwise come to expect from her work. She here tells the story of Ned and Jack - two very different English-men (sorry, one is Scottish) who end up working together in India after having been forced to move there due to personal circumstances.I was very fascinated by the description of life in India, and believe it to be fairly accurate - or at least in accordance to what I've been told by other people/books. The descriptions of the characters were well done and interesting, although occasionally rather stereotypical. While not exactly a page-turner, I was kept well entertained during the first 500 pages, and was prepared to give it a high recommendation.Unfortunately, the last 94 pages made me change my mind. Suddenly the book turned very dark, and the ending was a lot bleaker than the rest of the book had led me to believe it would be. That in itself didn't bother me too much (I prefer happy endings, but can accept that sometimes it just wouldn't make sense), but the fact that it seemed unnecessary - or even pointless - to have it end this way did. It may be that she's paving the way for a sequel, in which case the ending may prove to be justified, but as of now, there's no indication that this is the case, and therefore a lot of my enjoyment of the book was removed.Still worth reading though, but be prepared for a less-than-happy ending.

Fiona McIntosh is a magnificent storyteller and this novel had me turning the pages like a crazed woman to find out what transpired between Jack, Ned and Iris. And boy, wasn't I in for a shock at what took place in the exotic location of Kolar Gold Fields, India. Practically from the start this tale was fraught with sadness. It's a tragic story of love, loss and betrayal. The last 100 or so pages became gloomy and so totally unexpected but in my eyes the ending was perfectly satisfying. I don't enjoy books where the closing isn't fulfilling and yes, a sequel would be most welcomed but I honestly think the ending was unique and I find it boring to read every book with a predictable conclusion.My first read by this author and if any of her novels are as intriguing and compelling as this one I'm in for a seriously exquisite treat.The author's note at end is fascinating. Highly, highly recommended.

Jack Bryant from Cornwall and Ned Sinclair from Scotland end up in India after taking very different routes to get there and having very different reasons for being there. Jack fled England after an accident at the mine he worked at in Cornwall, and Ned and his sister, Bella, fled the orphange they were placed in after both their parents died in Burma. Jack and Ned make friends and end up working at the Kolar Gold Fields. They also both fall in love with the same woman, Iris Walker.I believe Fiona McIntosh is in her element in historical dramas/romance, and I happily went along for the ride in this book. So much so, that I wouldn't mind knowing what happened next...

Jack is from Cornwall and has everything handed to him on a plate. His good looks, a family who is well-off, a job above-ground at a goldmine. A mine accident changes Jack's life. He sets sail for Australia but on the way is talked into going to India instead. Ned is from Scotland and he travels with his sister and mother to meet up with their father who went for work in Burma. On their arrival they are met with tragedy and the two children find themselves alone in a strange country with no money. The time they spend in an orphanage is heart-breaking.Jack and Ned meet in Bangalore and form a friendship then find themselves having to keep a dark secret for many years. Great story!
Family saga covering many families, many towns and three country's.A delight to read, from an author who can tell a story. Well crafted, well paced.

The setting of this book, post the Great War, in India’s colourful fields of gold, appealed to the reader in me. It is a story of two men, the first, Jack Bryant, is a charming womanizer who is seeking to escape from a tragedy that has taken place at his family’s mine in Cornwall. The second man, Edward ‘Ned’ Sinclair is on the run after escaping family problems and seeks solace in the city of Bangalore, where he meets Jack. The pair become firm friends working in the mining community but eventually find themselves in a tangle of secrets and betrayals when they both end up falling in love with the same women. It follows a storyline that is packed full of complexities and character dilemmas, which at times I found a little hard going. The novel does a good job of capturing the culture and essence of India in post war times. I found it interesting that at the close of the book, Fiona McIntosh revealed that the inspiration for this book came from her two Grandfathers, which breathes more life into this novel for the reader. Fields of Gold is a different style of book to McIntosh’s other historical novels I have enjoyed more, such as The Lavender Keeper, The French Promise and The Tailor’s Girl, but it still makes for a solid read.

Loved the setting for this tale. I've been to India three times and felt Fiona captures the mood of India perfectly. The noise, the crowds, the vibrant colours were all conveyed exactly as they should have been. The story follows the lives of 2 young adventures, Ned and Jack, both of whom are running from aspects of their past. The story took me a while to get into and I dont know why I kept getting Ned and Jack mixed up.The inevitable love triangle rears its ugly head and things get complicated. For the whole novel I felt an unease that made me think we were heading for doom and gloom. This feeling made it impossible for me to really enjoy the novel.The ending had a few sharp turns and the main players did some things that were out of character and quite shallow and selfish.So I liked it but it didnt lose me in the story and I wasnt kept up late at night turning its pages like a woman possessed.

Fields of Gold by Fiona McIntosh was a reflection of her other novels. Fiona writes a great story, this one bringing together Ned and Jack in India as young men. Each of the characters have their own issues and challenges and they become good friends. The plots in Fiona's novels are always intriguing and indeed keep the reader reading. This was a love story of sorts with all the excitement and drama of a chocolate box story. At times I felt the coincidences were a little too contrived, but it did not stop me wanting to see where the novel's course would finish. The settings were beautifully described and the tensions of the relationships were real. A great story to be recommended.

Set in the 1920’s Fields of Gold is a story of two British men, Ned and Jack, who meet in India as young men. Drawn together because of a dark secret, they become close friends. The description of life in India at that time is fascinating. The characters are well drawn and the story of the loves, betrayals and dangers the two friends and the women in their lives experience make for compelling reading.I found the ending less than ideal, with several of the characters changing their personality traits in a manner that I found not totally plausible. However, up until this rather unsatisfying ending I thoroughly enjoyed the story.

Fiona McIntosh is one of my favourite authors. I saw her speak a number of years ago on a panel of historic fiction writers and have been reading her books ever since. She writes with rich detail, regardless of whether it's a fantasy setting or a period in the past. This story is no exception. It follows two young men in the years following the Great War, the majority of the story is set in India, a country I visited last year and have always loved. It's an interesting period of Indian history, the British had dominated for so long but their time was coming to an end, there are hints of this in Fields of Gold.

My 2nd book by this awesome author!Set at the end of WW2,2 young men find themselves far from home, hoping to start new lives in India's fields of gold! They form a bond like no other, bound by a dark secret from their past; but when their love for the same woman steps in, their lives become irreversibly changed!A blockbuster of a novel, with a wonderful colorful descriptive narrative, yet another unputadownable book!!

I was unable to finish this novel. Despite rave reviews, it failed to impress. The plot and characters were both terribly cliche and predictable. I gave up 300 pages in, I kept hoping for something to once again grab my interest but McIntosh has failed with this. A rambling, Mills & Boons-esque drama with no real purpose.

This was an enjoyable read, and I found myself pulled into the story and its characters. I thought the woman both main characters fall for, not very sympathetic, but she was a realistic product of her time and upbringing. I also loved the descriptions and the 'feel' of the time period. Recommended for readers who like a realistic historical background, characters and a multi-layered plot.

Another great read by Fiona McIntosh. I enjoy how easy to read her books are - I can easily follow the story, the characters are well developed and the stories take you to different and interesting locations.This book was less romantic than her other books I have read recently which was great.Her books are a bit long, this one could have been 50 pages shorter without losing the story.

After getting into this book...I really liked it, until near the close of the book, the characters had all dramatically changed, and the ending was totally dis-satisfying especially knowing there is no sequel.

Reading the author's note at the end made me like the story even more than I had already. It's a powerful story with some strong characters. I'm interested that Fiona McIntosh has also used the dual male protagonist angle in The Lavender Keeper.

Set in India in the 1920's, the author has done a great job of capturing the atmosphere of the time. I was quickly caught up in the story of Jack and Ned and thoroughly enjoyed this novel. A little disappointed by fairly abrupt ending but perhaps Fiona had toyed with the idea of a sequel.

This was a rich and sensual read. I prefer McIntosh's fantasy but that's just me. There was much to enjoy in this book. I felt immersed in the emotions of her characters. Recommended for those who love historical fiction.

Received this as a gift, not something I would have picked for myself, loved it, read it in one sitting, could not put it down. The ending left me wanting more, but that is the hallmark of a well woven tale. A wonderful piece of work.

A historical fiction story set mostly in India. Two young British men strike up a surprising friendship in the exotic world of India in the 1920s. The romances and betrayals lead the reader along and my only complaint is the slightly rushed ending.

Two men cross paths in Indian and become life long friends. Set in the 1920's, their journeys up until they meet are vastly different, but none less dramatic. I felt short changed by it's ending, but all in all the story was amazing - I totally enjoyed the historical fiction!

Set in Cornwall, Burma and India, this title follows the lives and loves of two British men whose paths cross in India. They become good friends but share a dangerous secret. The characters are sometimes hard to believe in, although the focus is on their relationships with each other.
After reading all her other historical fictions I thought I'd better read the first one... Fantastic setting but I found I didn't like the main characters enough.
Loved it - hard to put down - though sad ending
Read this book in Townsville
Very enjoyable book to read. The ending can be a let down.
Loved the book. Kept my interest till the end.
This was an ok book. Got a bit dull and far fetched at times.

description: At the end of the Great War, two young men find themselves far from home, with everything to gain or everything to lose…Charismatic womaniser Jack Bryant has the world at his feet, but when trouble catches up with him he's forced to flee Britain for good.Handsome, honest Ned Sinclair is on a family adventure in Rangoon when he is dealt a bitter blow. With all the odds against him, he risks his life in a desperate bid to escape. Both men hope to start their lives anew, seeking their fortune in India's fields of gold. Their paths collide in the colourful city of Bangalore, where they form a friendship like no other. In the years that follow, they remain inextricably bound by a dark secret, while their love for the same woman threatens to tear them apart.From the windswept clifftops of the Cornish coast to the goldmines of southern India, this is a page-turning story of high adventure, devastating tragedy and enduring love.
title: Fields of Gold
